explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though classified as "flammable" according to ICSC (2004).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 634degC (ICSC, 2004)

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 53degC (ICSC, 2004), test temperature: 140degC)

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 1,120mg/kg (MOE Risk Assessment vol.3 (2004)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: A report on rabbit skin irritation tests suggest that the substance is "non-irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) while epidemiological cases provide evidence of "skin, eye and mucosal irritation as major effects" (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999)). These equivocal data do not allow the degree of skin irritation to be determined, and thus classification is not possible.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (IUCLID (2000)): "slightly irritating" and "corrosive." In classification, priority was given to the severer reactions (i.e., "corrosive"), and thus classified into Category 1.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin sensitizer: Category 1
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: Based on an epidemiological case report of skin sensitization (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999)) and two case reports of positive patch test reactions (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999), MOE Risk Assessment vol.3 (2004))

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ/somatic cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and the absence of strong positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999), NTP DB (Access on February 2006)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 by ACGIH (2001).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on reproduction at dosing levels toxic to parental animals or in the absence of data on parental toxicity, described in CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "major effects include irritation of the skin/eye/mucosa, methemoglobinemia and effects on the urinary organs" (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "bladder damage, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure and eczema as clinical symptoms of poisoning" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and the evidence from animal studies including "anemia" (IRIS (1987)), "dose-dependent decreases in RBC count/hematocrit, statistically significant at medium to high doses" (JMPR (1998)), "renal tubular dilation, reversible anemia; histopathological changes were limited to the urinary organs, associated with interstitial nephritis and cystic dilation of the renal tubules" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (blood) and Category 2 (kidneys).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 72 hours ErC50=360microg/L of the algae (Green Algae) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3, 2004).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (BCF=253(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data, )), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.
